items.title: Effective Altruism
items.desc: The community that taught me to ask: what's actually the most impactful thing I can do? Rigorous, quantitative, and asking the right questions.

items.title: EA Switzerland
items.desc: We started EA Geneva, it grew into a national association. Now it's got great employees and we're just members of the club.

items.title: Simon Institute for Longterm Governance
items.desc: Helping the international community navigate frontier AI. Where the rabbit hole from animal rights to EA to biosecurity eventually led.

items.title: Slate Star Codex / Astral Codex Ten
items.desc: The best blog on the internet. Psychiatry, prediction markets, coordination failures, and everything in between.

items.title: Cold Takes
items.desc: Long-form thinking about the most important century, AI, and how to navigate transformative change.

items.title: Carl Shulman
items.desc: Possibly the most careful thinker alive on AI trajectories and their implications. Rarely writes, always worth reading.

items.title: LessWrong
items.desc: The rationalist community's home base. Epistemics, AI alignment, decision theory. Dense but rewarding.

items.title: Sonia Calico
items.desc: Taiwanese DJ/producer. Experimental club, deconstructed, relentless energy.

items.title: Acid Pauli
items.desc: Psychedelic electronic music. Organic, deeply textured, impossible to sit still to.

items.title: Tyler, the Creator
items.desc: Genre-bending hip-hop auteur. From Goblin to CHROMAKOPIA — relentless creative evolution.

items.title: Donald Glover / Childish Gambino
items.desc: Music, film, comedy, writing. The closest thing to a modern renaissance human in pop culture.

items.title: Zugezogen Maskulin
items.desc: German rap with teeth. Political, sardonic, Berlin-raw.

items.title: Sense8
items.desc: Eight strangers across the world share consciousness. The most earnest show about human connection ever made.

items.title: Everything Everywhere All at Once
items.desc: Multiverse absurdism that somehow becomes the most emotionally devastating film about kindness and laundry.

items.title: Hanabi
items.desc: Cooperative card game where you can see everyone's hand but your own. Pure coordination problem. Reveals how you communicate.

items.title: Secret Hitler
items.desc: Social deduction at its best. Trust, betrayal, and watching your friends lie to your face. Uncomfortably good training for real-world politics.

items.title: SIGG Bottle
items.desc: Swiss-made, indestructible, beautiful. The only water bottle you'll ever need.

items.title: Mobility Car-Sharing
items.desc: Switzerland's car-sharing network. 3,000+ vehicles, no ownership, works perfectly. The reason I don't own a car.

items.title: 80,000 Hours Podcast
items.desc: Three-hour deep dives on the world's most pressing problems and how to solve them. The most consistently excellent podcast on doing good.

items.title: Rationally Speaking
items.desc: Sharp, clear-headed conversations about rationality and science. Julia is the host I trust most to push back on guests.

items.title: Sean Carroll's Mindscape
items.desc: A physicist with genuine range. Consciousness, morality, quantum mechanics, aliens — all treated with the same intellectual seriousness.

items.title: EconTalk
items.desc: Economics as a lens on everything. Russ models intellectual humility better than almost anyone in media.

items.title: The Knowledge Project
items.desc: Decision-making, mental models, and how to think clearly. The Barbara Coloroso episode is secretly a masterclass in human interaction.

items.title: Making Sense
items.desc: Consciousness, AI, morality. Hit or miss on politics, but the episodes on minds and meditation are unmatched.

items.title: You Are Not So Smart
items.desc: Cognitive biases, self-delusion, and why your brain lies to you. The ads are annoying but the content earns them.

items.title: Future of Life Podcast
items.desc: Existential risk, AI safety, and paradise engineering. The Sam Barker & David Pearce episode on art and existential hope is a hidden gem.

items.title: Actually Possible: Thoughts on Utopia
items.desc: The most beautiful thing I've read about what a good future could actually look like. Not sci-fi, not naive — just careful, honest hope.

items.title: The Role of Tribes in Achieving Lasting Impact
items.desc: Nora and I wrote up our models for collectively engineering your social circles for positive-sum games. Your tribe defines your impact.

items.title: Our World in Data: Problems and Progress
items.desc: The single best antidote to doomerism. Rigorous, data-driven, and a reminder that humanism has come far in little time.

items.title: The economies that are home to the poorest billions need to grow
items.desc: Why redistribution alone can't solve poverty — the global average income is $16/day. The arithmetic case for growth.

items.title: Shut Up or Share? Three Steps to Combat Misinformation
items.desc: My TEDx on our well of common knowledge — cognitive biases, pandemic preparedness, probabilistic thinking. Too much for 17 minutes but I tried.

items.title: Creating a Voice for Future Generations in the Multilateral System
items.desc: How to reduce existential risk via the UN system. Spoiler: it's mainly via international narratives and norms.

items.title: A Computational Turn in Policy Process Studies
items.desc: We modeled policy processes as coevolving networks. An actor's influence depends on their environment and on exogenous events facilitating dialogue.

items.title: Policymaking for the Long-term Future: Improving Institutional Fit
items.desc: Introducing long-term institutional fit — spatial, temporal, functional, and representational — as a framework for future-proof governance.

items.title: A Very Short Guide to Decision-making on Wicked Problems
items.desc: A neat overview of state-of-the-art decision science. Max and I wrote it, I edited and layouted it.
